p: Our work, illustrated with P. pinaster, provides an approach to assess abiotic and biotic exposure with regards to climate change. Nevertheless, other factors could be considered to better characterize the exposure of the species to climate change. For instance, fire should be incorporated as an additional abiotic factor, as it plays an important role in pine biology [ 29, 84], while other pests, such as the pine processionary moth ( Thaumetopoea pityocampa Den. & Schiff. [ 85]) or the pine weevil ( Hylobius abietis L. [ 86]), should also be included.
